columns.text: This task aims to determine the maximum lease payment acceptable to a company, considering the equipment has an after-tax residual value of $\$900,000$ at the end of the lease.

Let´s first recall, ***what is the residual value?***

The **Residual value or salvage value** refers to the value of a property when the lease ends. It can be included in lease or buying evaluation considering its effects over depreciation: 

- If the residual value is zero, the depreciation can be calculated using the straight-line method by dividing the cost of the equipment by the years of life. 

- If the residual value is different from zero, this value must be deducted from the equipment's cost before dividing by years of life:
$$
\text{Depreciation} =\frac{(\text{Cost of equipment} – \text{Residual value})}{\text{years of life}}$$

It is essential to notice these values are pre-tax!

Now, ***what is the maximum lease payment that would be acceptable to the company?***

The **maximum lease payment** that would be acceptable to the company is the one that equals the cost of leasing with the cost of buying. In other words, ***the value that makes the $\mathbf{NPV}$ and $\mathbf{NAL}$, zero***.

To calculate determine the maximum lease payment we have the given information:
|Variable| Value| |:--:|:--:| |Computer-assisted drilling system| $\$ 7,300,000$| |Depreciation| Straight-line| |Lifetime (years)| $5$| |Tax rate |$21\%$| |Before tax cost of debt| $8\%| |After-tax residual value | $\$900,000.00$|
Table 1. The givens. Let's start! ## First step: Introduce all the givens in the spreadsheet. See Figure 1.

Figure 1. Given information introduced in a spreadsheet.

## Step 2: Calculation of After-tax discount rate or cost of debt To calculate the After-tax rate we apply the following formula: $$ \begin{align*} \text{After-tax rate} &= \text{Tax rate}\times (1 – \text{Cost of debt before tax})\\[10pt] &= 0.21 \times (1-0.21)\\[10pt] &= 0.0632 \end{align*} $$ The after-tax discount rate is $6.32\%$. ## Step 3: Calculation of Pre-tax residual value To calculate the Pre-tax residual value we apply the following formula: $$ \begin{align*} \text{Pre-tax residual value} &=\frac{ \text{After-tax residual value}}{(1- \text{Tax rate})}\\[10pt] &=\frac{\$900,000}{(1- 0.21)}\\[10pt] &=\$1,139,241 \end{align*} $$ We can use the spreadsheet to calculate this as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. After-tax discount rate and Pre-tax residual value.

## Step 4: Define depreciation schedule. The calculation of depreciation is straight-line over five years with a residual value of $\$900,000$. Then we can say the value of the machine is going to be depreciated as follows: - Every year will depreciate $\frac{1}{5} = 20\%$ of its total value minus the residual value, which is: $$20\% \times (\$7,300,000 - \$900,000) = \$1,232,152 \text{ per year.}$$ Then, we can add to our spreadsheet the depreciation schedule and pre-tax and after-tax lease payments as shown in figure 3:

Figure 3. Depreciation schedule and lease payments.

Now we can estimate the cash flows of leasing! ## Step 4: Define the cash flows of the leasing. - Lost depreciation tax shield is: $$\$1,232,152 \times 0.21 = \$258,752$$ From the previous section we know that: - Lease payments per year amount: $\$1,625,000$. - After-tax lease payment can be calculated as: $$\$1,625,000 \times(1-0.21) = \$1,283,7500$$ - The drilling system costs $\$7,300,000$. Then, cash flows can be defined in our spreadsheet as shown in Figure 4:

Figure 4. Cash flow of the leasing.

## Step 5: Calculate the $\mathbf{NPV}$ which is express the $\mathbf{NAL}$. $$ \begin{align*} \operatorname{NPV} &= \$7,300,000 – \$1,542,502 \times\frac{1-\dfrac{1}{1.0632^5}}{0.0632} \\[10pt] &= \boxed{\$858,596} \end{align*} $$ Using the spreadsheet it can be also calculated using the **NPV** function by deducting the $\operatorname{NPV}$ of cash flows from the cost of buying the drilling system. See Figure 5:

Figure 5. Summarize of exercise and NPV calculation details.

***Net Advantage to Leasing is $\bold{\$858,596}$***. The $\operatorname{NPV}$ is positive, which means ***leasing is preferred over buying the drilling system***. In other words, the expected cash flows from leasing are higher than the cash flows from buying.

Now, $$ \begin{align*} \text{Annual cash flow}&= \text{After tax lease payment} + \text{Lost depreciation tax shield}\\[10pt] \$1,748,107.09 &= \text{Lease value}\times(1-0.21) + \$258,752\\[10pt] \text{Lease value}&= \frac{\$1,748,107.09 - \$258,752}{(1-0.21)}\\[10pt] &= \frac{\$ 1,489,355.09}{ 0.79}\\[10pt] &= \boxed{\$ 1,885,259.61} \end{align*} $$ ***The maximum lease payment that would be acceptable to Wildcat if the equipment has a residual value of $\bold{\$900,000}$ is $\bold{\$ 1,885,259.61}$***.
